headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly. Good morning, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Call. Our earnings release presentation and related financial information are available on our website at aes.com.Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly. Good morning, and welcome to our Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Call. Our earnings release presentation and related financial information are available on our website at aes.com.
Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during the call. There are many factors that may cause future results to differ materially from these statements. Please refer to our SEC filings for a discussion of these factors.
Joining me to this morning are Andres Gluski, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Mary Wood, our Interim Chief Financial Officer; and other senior members of our management team.
With that, I will now turn the call over to Andres.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ahmed, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our Second Quarter Earnings Call. Let me start by saying that I'm very pleased to announce that Tom O'Flynn will be joining us as our new CFO in September. Tom is a great addition to our man
componenttext:
Thanks, Ahmed, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our Second Quarter Earnings Call. Let me start by saying that I'm very pleased to announce that Tom O'Flynn will be joining us as our new CFO in September. Tom is a great addition to our management team and brings a strong combination of financial skills, senior corporate experience and extensive knowledge of the energy and infrastructure sectors.
I'm looking forward to working with Tom to execute on our plans to deliver long-term value to our shareholders.
I would also like to take a moment to thank Mary Wood for doing a great job as interim CFO over the past 90 days. Once Tom is on board, Mary will resume her prior position in the finance organization as our Controller. 
Now as you might have seen in our press release, we are at $0.18 of adjusted EPS for the second quarter. And although this is below below last year's level, our results year-to-date of $0.55 are in line with our commitment to our full year guidance. Mary will walk you through the specific drivers later in this call.
Turning to Slide 3, I will provide you with an update on the strategic plan that we laid out late last year to unlock shareholder value. I will then discuss some of the key macro trends affecting the portfolio, as well as recent developments in our more significant businesses.  And following Mary's review our financial results, I will discuss our capital allocation plan for the remainder of the year.
Moving to Slide 4, and just as a reminder, our 3 strategic objectives for unlocking shareholder value are: One, optimizing capital allocation; two, growing the profitability of the existing portfolio; and three, narrowing our geographic and business focus by selling nonstrategic assets.
We feel we're making good progress on executing on the strategic plans we laid out. Regarding the narrowing of our geographic focus, we have raised $800 million through asset sales, excited several non-core markets and invested most of these proceeds to strengthen our balance sheet.
At the same time, we're improving the profitability of our business by cutting costs, exploring scale in synergies and making high return investments based on our existing platforms.
Now turning to Slide 5. Let me provide some color on how we're optimizing our capital allocation and considering all uses of discretionary tax, including de-levering, share repurchases, project and increases in our dividend to improve our total shareholder return.
Over the last 9 months, we have made earlier payment on approximately $500 million of debt between repaying the corporate revolver and paying down the expensive debt at our Brazilian subsidiary in Brazil. With respect to share repurchases, since our last call, we have bought back more than 20 million shares for a total investment of $252 million. This brings our cumulative share repurchases since September  to 29 million shares or about 4% of those outstanding.
Our total investment in our stock since September is more than $341 million, implying an average purchase price of $11.57 per share. Additionally, last week, the board approved a quarterly dividend of $0.04 per share, our first cash dividend payment in almost 20 years. We expect to grow the dividend over time in accordance with the performance the company and market conditions.  The dividend is and will remain an integral part of our total value proposition.
Now please turn to Slide 6. And let's discuss our actions to improve our profitability. We've committed to achieving $50 million of cost savings at the parent level in 2012 and a total of $100 million in cost savings per year by the end of 2013. For 2012, we expect to exceed our target, and are now projecting at least $65 million in savings this year, as we've already reduced SG&A by $31 million during the first 6 months.
Moving to Slide 7, let us review our progress in terms of narrowing our geographic and business focus too the asset sale program. Despite a challenging market, we have closed or signed additional deals such as our French win and China portfolios for additional proceeds of $176 million. To date, we've closed our ninth asset sales in September  first quarter motive proceeds to AES of $932 million.
Thus far, we've achieved attractive valuations for these assets at an average P/E multiple of more than 20x 2011 adjusted earnings. In summary, we believe that we are consistently executing on the plans that we laid out last November.
Next, on Slide 8, I'd like to briefly discuss important macroeconomic trends affecting our portfolio. We have seen a weakening of GDP growth in some of our markets, including Brazil, where the current year GDP growth rate is expected to be about 2% versus prior expectations of 4%. This is also reflected in a 19% year-over-year depreciation of the Brazilian real.
Demand for electric power at Brazil this year expected to grow only about 1%. Nonetheless, over the medium term, we expect growth in Brazil to recover from closer to 4% level and demand for power to grow in line with GDP. In many of our other markets, we're seeing more robust economic growth.
For example, Chile and Colombia's economies are growing at nearly 5% and power demand increasing at up to 7% on some of the grids. Regarding our key markets in the U.S., Ohio's economy is expected to grow in line with the overall U.S. economy at about 2%, while Indiana is slightly lower at about 1%.
This year, power demand is increasing at roughly 1% to 1.5% at our Midwestern utilities and forecast expect a slight pickup next year.
Generally speaking, weaker commodity prices have negatively affected our results year-to-date. On the natural gas front, while we have seen a modest supply side correction and a fall in the gas-only rig counts, prices remain near the $3 per million BTU range, a result of both of our utilities in the U.S. but much more so at DP&L, were positively correlated to U.S. natural gas price.
Regarding oil and coal prices, both have weakened over the past quarter. The broad brush strokes, although our portfolio is roughly 1/3 hydro and renewables, 1/3 natural gas and 1/3 coal, our results are positively correlated to oil prices. Directly those markets where fewer or lower diesel set the marginal price and in others where set by natural gas or LNG linked to oil prices.
On the other hand, AES' results are negative correlated to coal prices, and we're starting to se the benefits from recent price declines. Today, we're in a buyers market, and we are leveraging our aggregated annual spend of nearly $2 billion on solid fuels, unlocking attractive prices for the remainder of the year.
To summarize, our commodity prices have rebounded slightly as of late. Current forward curves still imply a negative EPS impact of around $0.04 relative to where forward curves were as of March 31.
Despite this, we've taken the necessary actions to maintain our adjusted earnings per share forecast within our original guidance range.
Now I would like to give an update on some recent developments at our more prominent businesses. Let's start with Eletropaulo on Slide 9. The electricity regulator in Brazil, issued the final ruling on Eletropaulo's tariff reset on July 2. The final tariff reset represented a larger decline than the April preliminary proposal, and is thus more negative than we had expected.  The variance in the final ruling compared to the April proposal was mainly attributable to the change in the benchmark used to determine the level of non-technical energy losses included in the tariff.
It's important to mention that we have positive track record of improving Eletropaulo's operations through reduced energy losses, cost management and revenue enhancement. Since 2010, AES Brazil has implemented the creating value program, which has contributed approximately BRL 325 million riyals about $160 million to the bottom line through greater productivity and efficiency.
Although we are disappointed with the regulatory outcome at Eletropaulo, I would like to point out that our 2 other Brazilian businesses, Tietê and Zoll, are performing in line with expectations. These 2 businesses represent more than 80% of our earnings from Brazil as we only own 16% of Eletropaulo.
Now turning to Slide 10, I'd like to give an update on DP&L. The business continues to perform this year in line with our expectations. In terms of customer switching, at the end of June, 56% of the load had switched to competitive providers, up 3% from the end of March. I would like to highlight that Diplir, our retail arm, captured more than 78% of the switched loads through the second quarter. As you know, DP&L's current rate plan is set to expire on December 31, 2012.
In March, DP&L filed for approval of its next standard service offering in the form of a market rate offer, or MRO, for 2013 and beyond. At this point, we're in the midst of settlement discussions, the process is constructive but complex, given the number of interveners and the diversity of positions.
Combined with continued low natural gas prices, some of the potential regulatory outcomes that have been proposed by very interveners could result in lower medium-term earnings and cash flows from this business.
We continue to work towards an outcome that is very reasonable for all stakeholders, and we remain hopeful that we will have a resolution in the third quarter or early in the fourth quarter.
Overall, contributions from this business will depend heavily on the final outcome of the MRO.
In the meantime, we're positioning this business for success in the competitive marketplace by expanding our retail capabilities and enhancing the efficiency of our North American portfolio. DP&L's retailer marketing business, declare, and MC Squared, are rapidly expanding in markets beyond DP&L's service territory.
We are now serving more than 140,000 customers outside of our service area in Dayton, representing annual usage of about 2.5 million-megawatt hours. This growth more than offset 70,000 customers and 2.1 million-megawatt hours that have switched to unaffiliated third-party on DP&L's system.
Overall, for 2012, we're projecting that DP&L's Retail business will serve approximately 200,000 customers with combined annual retail sales of 8 million-megawatt hours.
In terms of reducing costs, AES is on track to achieve nearly $10 million in synergy savings across its North American per portfolio businesses this year, and we are aggressively pursuing additional opportunities.
Moving to Slide 11, we are seeing positive momentum and some of our other businesses in the portfolio. For example, in the Philippines, our Masinloc plant achieved record performance in May and June. We have seen similar transit at our Kilroot plant in Northern Ireland, and we have benefited from lower coal prices.
Overall, while in the last quarter, we faced headwinds at some of our businesses, given the results of our portfolio year-to-date, we are confident that we can deliver on our adjusted EPS and proportional cash flow guidance for 2012, which as you know, represents a roughly 20% increase over 2011.
Looking beyond 2012, as I discussed on our last call, we faced some challenges in 2013, including low capacity and natural gas prices at DP&L. In 2014 and '15, we see favorable trends, including improved capacity prices in PGM, greater demand growth in key markets such as Brazil, Chile and Colombia, improved earnings from our wind portfolio, contributions from our current construction projects and value creation for our capital allocation decisions.
Over the medium term, we remain optimistic about our earnings trajectory and business prospects. The new capital allocation strategy has improved returns on new projects by focusing on utilizing passion local leverage capacity and expanding on existing platforms.  We're focusing on those platform expansion projects that require little equity from AES and shorter lead times to make the greatest contributions to the bottom line.
The near-term examples of these types of projects include Hana, a 20-megawatt Hydro facility related to our 1,000-megawatt hydro plant in Colombia. In the 52 megawatt of lithium ion battery facilities co-located with the Angamos and Deepwater plants. Another potential project is the closing of the open cycle at the Los Mina's plant and making greater use of our Andres facility in the Dominican Republic.
So these projects will be constructed relatively quickly, require less equity from AES and will generate earnings faster than Greenfield construction.
As far as 2013 is concerned, we will issue guidance no later than the Fourth Quarter Earnings Call.
Now Mary will review the drivers of our quarterly results and our 2012 guidance in more detail. Gary?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andres, and good morning, everyone. This morning, beginning on Slide 12, I will cover the following topics: First, our second quarter results and key drivers of proportional gross margin, adjusted earnings per share, cash flow from operations and
componenttext:
Thanks, Andres, and good morning, everyone. This morning, beginning on Slide 12, I will cover the following topics: First, our second quarter results and key drivers of proportional gross margin, adjusted earnings per share, cash flow from operations and free cash flow; second, current liquidity; and finally, our 2012 guidance.
As Andres mentioned, we reported $0.18 of adjusted earnings per share for the second quarter and $0.55 for the first half of 2012. For our first half results, we are still in line with our internal expectations for the full year.
Later in my remarks, I will walk through what we see as the key drivers of adjusted EPS for the second half of this year, and why we believe that full year results will still be in line with our guidance range of $1.22 to $1.30, although at the lower end.
Before covering the results in more detail, I would like to provide some perspective on the year-over-year decline in adjusted EPS we experienced this quarter.
First, during the second quarter of 2011, Kinner in Chile had a strong quarter due to significant spot sales at favorable prior prices. We do not expect that opportunity to reoccur in 2012, and we project lower results from this business in the second quarter of this year.
Panera also had some planned and unplanned outages at its coal-fired facilities during the second quarter of this year. The lower volume also contributed to the year-over-year trend.  All affected plants are back on line and performing in line with our expectations. 
Second, early results included an additional and final adjustment to the new Tara for Eletropaulo recently approved by the regulator, which was a tougher outcome than anticipated and required a catch-up accrual.  These factors affecting 2 of our more significant businesses explain much of the year-over-year decline. These headwinds were partially offset by contributions from our new businesses, which are expected to continue to make significant year-over-year contributions in the second half of 2012.
Now turning to Slide 13, our proportional gross margin decreased by $56 million compared to the second quarter of 2011. Gener recorded a reduction of $60 million, approximately half due to lower spot sales and half due to lower plant availability.
The proportional gross margin impact of the Eletropaulo tariff reset was $35 million for the quarter, including a catch-up accrual of $12 million.  This represents the final adjustment for the tariff decision as we have been accruing for the outcome since the third quarter of 2011.
In addition, unfavorable foreign currency exchange rates had an impact of $20 million. These trends were partially offset by the contributions of new businesses in the United States, Bulgaria and Latin America.
Turning to adjusted earnings per share on Slide 14, second quarter results decreased by $0.11 to $0.18. Gener in Chile accounted for $0.07 of the decline, Electropaolo, primarily due to the final tariff reset, represented $0.04 of the reduction. Offsetting these declines, new businesses contributed $0.04 during the quarter. A reduction in SG&A also added $0.02 for the quarter. Foreign exchange headwinds reduced adjusted EPS by $0.02 for the quarter, primarily driven by the Brazilian riel, which has depreciated by 19%.
Together, the operating drivers accounted for $0.07 of the decline. In terms of non-operating drivers, the quarterly effective tax rate was higher than the rate from the year-earlier due in part to a change in the book income mix, which resulted in a $0.03 reduction year-over-year.  We expect the reduction in the effective tax rate on a full year basis.
Now turning to cash flow on Slide 15. On a proportional basis, our free cash flow has increased 44% compared to the second quarter of 2011. This was driven by contributions from new businesses and a higher cash flow from Latin American generation due to improved working capital, partially offset by a decline at Eletropaulo adjusted for a 16% ownership stake.
Now I will review our parent liquidity as of the end of June on Slide 16. During the quarter, we benefited from $677 million of inflows from our asset sales and cash from our subsidiaries. During the quarter, we invested $230 million in share repurchases. After $323 million of corporate interests, overhead and investments, we ended the second quarter with more than $1 billion of parent liquidity, up from $911 million at the end of the first quarter.
We are pleased with our operating performance that provides us ample liquidity to increase value for our shareholders.
Turning to Slide 17, I'd like to discuss our outlook for the remainder of the year. Although we have phase significant headwinds, we expect to offset most of these with new businesses, operational improvements, cost reductions and capital allocation initiatives that we have been discussing for the last few quarters.
Accordingly, we are affirming our 2012 adjusted EPS and proportional free cash flow guidance, although we now expect to come in at the lower end of the range. Next, I will review the specific drivers of our second half of 2012 performance and how we expect to achieve our adjusted EPS target, the year-over-year changes in our businesses, as well as proactive steps that we have taken to improve our earnings.
Turning to Slide 18, our pro forma adjusted EPS was $0.56 in the second half of 2011, excluding the pre-closing interest cost from the $2 billion of parent debt that we issued to fund the acquisition of DP&L.
We believe that the performance of our businesses will be largely consistent with the second half of 2011. Beyond this, we expect to generate an additional $0.11 to $0.15 of earnings, with approximately 70% or $0.09 of this expected increase, driven by contributions from new businesses. As a reminder, Maritza, Changuinola and Angamos achieved full commercial operations late in the second half of 2011, and DP&L was acquired in late November.
In addition, our key initiatives such as cost-cutting, operational improvements in capital allocation are expected to contribute roughly $0.06. These gains are partially offset by year-over-year comedy and foreign exchange headwinds of approximately $0.03 to $0.04.  $0.11 to $0.15 of improvement that we are targeting in the second half of this year versus the second half of 2011 just put us in the lower end of our adjusted EPS guidance range of $1.22 to $1.30 for the year.
Although we expect the third and fourth quarters of 2012 to record gains year-over-year, the second half increase is more weighted towards the fourth quarter. As discussed in our last call, our guidance assumes the extension of the controlled foreign corporation our CFC look through provision, originally enacted under TIPRA. As in prior years, we expect Congress will retroactively extend the tax legislation later this year.  Based on actions taken last Thursday by the Senate Finance Committee, which voted for a 2-year extension, we continue to expect this will occur.
If the CFC looks extended before year end, we estimate an impact of $0.02 to $0.03 this year. Recall that this would be a noncash impact as we have an outstanding net operating loss balance of approximately $2.1 billion. Overall, we continue to project that tax rate in the low 30% range, generally in line with the rate we recorded in 2011.
Turning to our cash flow guidance on Slide 19. As we discussed on our last call, we expect our full year results to achieve lower end of our range of the portion of free cash flow, primarily as a result of working capital changes and assets sold this year.
We are also now guiding to the lower end of our range on subsidiary distributions, as we may elect to retain some operating cash at our key platform businesses such as Gener for tax-efficient investment purposes. In summary, we are pulling other levers available to us to meet our guidance despite the headwinds that we experienced in the last quarter.
I just would now I just our plans for capital allocation for the second half of 2012.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mary. And moving to Slide 20, I would like to discuss our plans for capital allocation for the balance of 2012. This year, we expect to generate $1.6 billion of discretionary cash. Year-to-date, we already allocated 61% to strengthening our bal
componenttext:
Thank you, Mary. And moving to Slide 20, I would like to discuss our plans for capital allocation for the balance of 2012. This year, we expect to generate $1.6 billion of discretionary cash. Year-to-date, we already allocated 61% to strengthening our balance sheet.
We have used another $145 million or 9% for our joint venture in Turkey and wind projects in the U.K. and Poland to realize the value of recent pipeline acquisitions.  We expect invest an additional $132 million in other growth opportunities during the second half of the year.
This leaves us with roughly $350 million of discretionary cash that we have not yet allocated. We will continue to update you on our capital location plan as we received the cash later this year.
Turning to Slide 21. In terms of future growth, our construction program or rates on schedule. Construction work at our 270-megawatt Campiche project in Chile is progressing well, and it's expected to commence operations in early 2013. This project, a 216-megawatt power plant in Cameroon is also expected to come online in 2013. Additionally, the 1,200-megawatt Mong Duong project in Vietnam is commercial group commercial operations in 2015 and similar construction rates are underway on the site. As a reminder, we have already made the necessary equity contributions and have committed nonrecourse debt financing for all of these construction projects.
In terms of future value creation, we will continue to focus on those markets and platforms where we have a significant presence and a compelling competitive advantage.
To that end, we're making markers and our advanced developing by pleasure Chile, Columbia and the U.S. In Chile, we have the Cochrane project, a 532-megawatt expansion adjacent to our newly commissioned and successful Angamos pant. We are also progressing on now to Mai Pogue, a 531-megawatt one of the River near Santiago that builds upon our existing facility.
In the U.S., we'll roll our platform at Indianapolis Power & Light with investments in environmental controls and some of our coal-fired generation units that will earn regulated returns.
Outside of the 3 biggest markets, we also see growth opportunities in the Philippines and India. We're working on Masinloc 2, a brownfield expansion of our very successful mass in the Masinloc plants in the Philippines, and India, we're pursuing an expansion of our OPGC facility and expect to be able to fund a substantial portion of our equity with local liquidity.
All development projects, we will utilize the most capital-efficient funding sources, including local cash generation and leverage capacity, however, possible to reduce the required AES equity contribution and improve AES' capital efficiency. 
In closing, we believe that the successful execution of our strategy consisting of disciplined capital allocation, platform expansions, cost cutting and efficiently initiatives will allow us to create more value for our shareholders.
With respect to the second half of 2012, we expect the contributions from our new plants and businesses which came online late last year, availability in Chile will deliver strong growth this year.
In summary, we expect to meet our commitment and achieve our adjusted EPS and proportional free cash flow guidance for 2012.
I look forward to visiting many of you with our newly appointed CFO, Tom O'Flynn, in the near future. Operator, we will now open the lines for questions.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jonathan Cohen.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jonathan Cohen.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the global credit environment and whether or not it's becoming more difficult to finance some of your growth and also refinance some of the amortization of the project that's
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the global credit environment and whether or not it's becoming more difficult to finance some of your growth and also refinance some of the amortization of the project that's coming due?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that in general, we can say that data financial conditions, especially in the project finance area. In our case, it can be, in some markets an advantage, where we have a strong platforms that we can get nonrecourse financing from those platfo
componenttext: Yes, I think that in general, we can say that data financial conditions, especially in the project finance area. In our case, it can be, in some markets an advantage, where we have a strong platforms that we can get nonrecourse financing from those platforms. We also have very strong relations with multilaterals such as the IFC and with bilateral credit agencies. So what we're doing now is changing from our project financing model to include more bilateral, multilateral financing and making greater use of the platforms. But really, this is playing to our strength and playing to our strong local presence and our strong relationship with these entities.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the decision to retain more cash in certain of these subsidiaries, is that in any way related to what you're seeing in the credit markets?
componenttext: Okay. So the decision to retain more cash in certain of these subsidiaries, is that in any way related to what you're seeing in the credit markets?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, no. In the sense that the subs, most of these -- a lot of these subs are investment-grade, we see that we don't have any issues with the refinancing. It's basically a decision given that we have a sufficiently -- sufficient liquidity at corporate, it'
componenttext: No, no. In the sense that the subs, most of these -- a lot of these subs are investment-grade, we see that we don't have any issues with the refinancing. It's basically a decision given that we have a sufficiently -- sufficient liquidity at corporate, it's much more efficient from a tax perspective not to bring money out of the country, pay a tax and put money back in. That's basically given that they have very attractive investment opportunities so we're seeing that we leave some cash in them. In other cases, in some of the other ones, we do have cash, for example, in India where we have not been able to dividend the money out. So between us and our which is the state government of Orissa, we have about $180 million that we're going to deploy that in an expansion of the facility. So there's a differentiation.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: And just 1 last question. If the tax extenders package does not get done, is that $0.02 to $0.03 headwind that you mentioned before enough to sort of Nokia the bottom end of the generation of that guidance range or do you have enough cushion in there to a
componenttext: And just 1 last question. If the tax extenders package does not get done, is that $0.02 to $0.03 headwind that you mentioned before enough to sort of Nokia the bottom end of the generation of that guidance range or do you have enough cushion in there to account for that?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: We -- this is Mary. We have not built the $0.02 into our guidance, although about $0.01 of it is reflected in our first half results. So that's something that we will have to address, although we feel very confident that we'll get extended.
componenttext: We -- this is Mary. We have not built the $0.02 into our guidance, although about $0.01 of it is reflected in our first half results. So that's something that we will have to address, although we feel very confident that we'll get extended.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andrea Strowski [ph] .
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrea Strowski [ph] .

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wanted to first talk about the long-term growth earnings guidance, so 7% to 9% in EPS growth, all in 2012. Do you -- I mean, I haven't heard you really reiterating that targets, and do you think it's still achievable given the macroeconomic backdrop tha
componenttext: I wanted to first talk about the long-term growth earnings guidance, so 7% to 9% in EPS growth, all in 2012. Do you -- I mean, I haven't heard you really reiterating that targets, and do you think it's still achievable given the macroeconomic backdrop that you're facing?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: What we are committed to is an 8% to 10% total return over the next 3 years. What we have said is there wouldn't be a straight line growth. And what we see is more challenges in '13. We see a lot of tailwinds helping us in '14 and '15. So we will manage t
componenttext: What we are committed to is an 8% to 10% total return over the next 3 years. What we have said is there wouldn't be a straight line growth. And what we see is more challenges in '13. We see a lot of tailwinds helping us in '14 and '15. So we will manage to that 8% to 10% total return, which of course includes our dividend. And we of course, we will update you once we have more information, for example, on what's happening in the various markets. But I think given our portfolio given the diversity of fuels that so we have, one of the things we will come back to you, if need be, is after the settlement of the MRO, for example, in the P&L. But we remain committed to that 8% to 10% total return, which is earnings growth plus dividends.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And secondly, I was other bit surprised to see share buybacks during the quarter because I felt that you are now planning to have an issue buybacks until the end of the year. And secondly, it seems like you are becoming a lot of it more aggressive w
componenttext: Okay. And secondly, I was other bit surprised to see share buybacks during the quarter because I felt that you are now planning to have an issue buybacks until the end of the year. And secondly, it seems like you are becoming a lot of it more aggressive with your retail strategy in Ohio for something that I didn't think was a focus. Could you comment on both?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Regarding the share buybacks, we have said that we would look at share buybacks as one of the uses of our cash, if we felt that there was a compelling valuation that would complete new projects. And in the past, we said that we would ask for an addi
componenttext: Sure. Regarding the share buybacks, we have said that we would look at share buybacks as one of the uses of our cash, if we felt that there was a compelling valuation that would complete new projects. And in the past, we said that we would ask for an additional approvals to have a bigger program. So we've been very much, I think, executing on what we said we would do. Regarding the retail market in the Midwest, perhaps Andy Vesey can comment on it. That's really part of our strategy of building off our platforms in specific markets.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Andy Vesey. In terms of your question on retail, it's one of the 3 levels we have at Dayton Power & Light, one is always to defend our current service territory, the customers there and also the system to track our customers. The whole theory area
componenttext: This is Andy Vesey. In terms of your question on retail, it's one of the 3 levels we have at Dayton Power & Light, one is always to defend our current service territory, the customers there and also the system to track our customers. The whole theory area behind our retail operations is really the placement of our generation at the P&L. It's the most a lot really efficiently way to do that. So our strategy in retail is to continue to gain customer so we could place some generation. We have to be aggressive because it's a very intense competitive environment. And it's a game that we play very hard.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ali Agha.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ali Agha.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, Andres. IF I do the math right, based on the share buyback which you completed so far, there's only about $50 million lap the your current authorization? Should we assume that authorization is going to get expanded, or how should we
componenttext: A couple of questions, Andres. IF I do the math right, based on the share buyback which you completed so far, there's only about $50 million lap the your current authorization? Should we assume that authorization is going to get expanded, or how should we be thinking about that future buybacks from this level?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: You're right, Ali. And there's about $48 million left in the authorization. We intend to use that and again, depending as we see our cash coming in and we see our growth again value with was the best use of that cash and as I said in the past, that hasn't
componenttext: You're right, Ali. And there's about $48 million left in the authorization. We intend to use that and again, depending as we see our cash coming in and we see our growth again value with was the best use of that cash and as I said in the past, that hasn't been a rejection for us. In terms of -- if we need to get more approvals, we will. But we will again have a balanced approach to capital location. We have growth projects, we've also de-levered to the strengthen our balance sheet, and we've also have the current dividend, and we have some growth prospects as well. So that's very much a balanced approach.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, and going back, Andres, to your 8% to 10% target annual return over the next 3 years or so, the earnings component of that, as you pointed out, DP&L will be a challenge certainly in '13. There's not much in terms of new projects coming on until '15 w
componenttext: Yes, and going back, Andres, to your 8% to 10% target annual return over the next 3 years or so, the earnings component of that, as you pointed out, DP&L will be a challenge certainly in '13. There's not much in terms of new projects coming on until '15 when 1,200 megawatts comes on. So when we look at that trajectory, '12 through '15, I wanted to get a sense from you, to me, buyback and debt reduction seemed to be the biggest tool available in your arsenal to achieve that. And I'm just wondering how you think about that? And how aggressively should be thinking about that buyback and debt reduction program for you in the next 3 years?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at, as I mentioned, in '14, '15, we have a number of headwinds besides just and -- first, we do have some of the investments we're making in the smaller platform expansions how whether it be to heat, whether it be battery, storage, whe
componenttext: I think if you look at, as I mentioned, in '14, '15, we have a number of headwinds besides just and -- first, we do have some of the investments we're making in the smaller platform expansions how whether it be to heat, whether it be battery, storage, whether it be closing the sites, those things will, and much faster, come online in that period. Also, realize that from an earnings perspective, due to the nature of the tax equity financing at our U.S. wind businesses. We have a substantial pickup in '14 and '15 in terms of earnings. So we do have those things coming on. We also expect more, say, demand growth in some of the markets. We know that there better capacity prices in PJM, which will also be a big pickup. So -- and not that we're just going to be relying on share buyback. I also think that we will have full years of the earning -- sorry, cost savings from the programs that we implemented this year and next in terms of becoming more efficient in terms of SG&A and other factors of costs. Because we are really looking at costs across our portfolio. So in the $65 million that we're talking about, that's really at the parent level. That does not include, for example, the efficiency initiatives on our North American portfolio. That does not include the initiatives in Brazil, in other markets. And so we do have an a lot of those areas, we are, I'd say, about halfway through some of those programs and we will practice accelerate them in the remainder of this year and next.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: And 1 other thing. On the asset sale program, can you just give us an update on what's your current thoughts are relative to your original goal? There were some news, as I'm sure you're aware, what you guys talking to the Chinese about the U.S. wind asset
componenttext: And 1 other thing. On the asset sale program, can you just give us an update on what's your current thoughts are relative to your original goal? There were some news, as I'm sure you're aware, what you guys talking to the Chinese about the U.S. wind asset sale that seems to have stalled down now. And so just give us a sense of where you are? And again, from a priority perspective, I know in the past, you talked about trying to monetize your renewables portfolio because you're not getting much in terms of equity value for that. Have you continue to believe that? Or what's your current thinking on the asset sales?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: We remain committed to our initial program. What we had said at the beginning was that we had a universe of about of $2 billion that we were looking at. We've executed about almost 50% of it. I think we've executed it very well because we sold at good pri
componenttext: We remain committed to our initial program. What we had said at the beginning was that we had a universe of about of $2 billion that we were looking at. We've executed about almost 50% of it. I think we've executed it very well because we sold at good prices and good earnings multiple. Going forward, we will be looking at is those things that really help us have a more focused portfolio, as well as help us reduce the cost of some of those support services that we have, and there are also businesses from which we think we cannot grow. So you're correct in the sense that we had looked at renewables because they were low on earnings. Because we said, that for example, if we look at U.S. wind today, we do really have that pickup in '14, '15, and that's in terms of our earnings. We also do have our solar joint venture with Riverstone, and we'll be looking together in ways of monetizing that over the future. So our -- I would like to get it specific cases prior to really having something concrete. But we are not really changing from our original position. I think we are executing well, but we're not going to do fire sales. We're going to make sure that we sell the assets in the right form to maximize price. For example, our China assets, there's one case where we did receive bids for it as one package, and we realized we could do much better by selling it apart. The difference is not favorable like $30 million. So we'll continue to execute, but we're going to do it in a prudent fashion.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Last question, I apologize. Given your commodity currency exposure, every quarter, these are moving target. And so just given the nature of your business, are you comfortable putting guiding set there because there's going to be movements every quarter, a
componenttext: Last question, I apologize. Given your commodity currency exposure, every quarter, these are moving target. And so just given the nature of your business, are you comfortable putting guiding set there because there's going to be movements every quarter, are there other assets that you have which are disposals, you are comfortable that when you put a guidance number out, it's going to be achieved regard as of the currency commodity move that are inevitable in every few months?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's the reason we give the range, and we don't move the range every quarter with the commodity prices. That's one of the drivers of our performance within that range. Now AES is a portfolio, and so generally, we do have assets. Sometimes,
componenttext: Yes, I think that's the reason we give the range, and we don't move the range every quarter with the commodity prices. That's one of the drivers of our performance within that range. Now AES is a portfolio, and so generally, we do have assets. Sometimes, the stars align a little bit so on a quarter basis, that's why we don't quite frankly give quarterly guidance because of that. But we do give yearly guidance. We are very conscious now of the portfolio exposures to the various commodities, and we are taking steps to try to mitigate that over time. So we, again, those are good questions, that's why we give yearly guidance, and we don't give quarterly guidance. And if you actually look what we are executing on, we are looking at a 20% plus increase in our earnings -- adjusted EPS this year. And we've taken a lot of steps and yes, we've had some headwinds. But that's to be expected.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012

componenttext: Our next question comes from Charles Fishman.

componenttext: In Eletropaulo, when you get the decision from ANEEL is final, in other words, you cannot appeal that subsequent to their final decision?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012

componenttext: Yes, I'll ask Andy to give you to answer that.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Chuck, Andrew Vesey. There are some things that can be done, and we've actually taken the first step, which is to file for administrative appeals and review. This is a normal process in Brazil after tariff review or administrative procedure of that may ha
componenttext: Chuck, Andrew Vesey. There are some things that can be done, and we've actually taken the first step, which is to file for administrative appeals and review. This is a normal process in Brazil after tariff review or administrative procedure of that may have done gone wrong. In our administrative filing, which was filed shortly after the case came out, we basically raised 2 key points. One was in the removal from the shielded assets -- excuse me, the shielded rate asset base of 2007 to 2011, of these particular cables. We believe that's a procedural and administrative integration to go in things should then asset base, as well as the loss benchmark that Andres has referred to earlier. In Brazil, this loss benchmark is used for over 40% of the distribution businesses, and shows that statistically, the benchmark was an outlier and therefore, we're appealing for both of those. Process for that, if there were to be a change or at a benefit that would come out of that, it probably would be applied at the time of the next half adjustment, which we would be July 2013 and be retroactive back to July 2011. We have done this in the past. We've had some movement, but given the force of the issues here, I don't want to raise false expectations. But we were already taken that action. Finally, at the end of the day, we should we still be concerned about the outcome, we always have like a Brazilian company would, to appeal it to the Supreme Court but in Brazil, that could be a process that could take many, many years.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012

componenttext: Actually, this is Andrew, stepping in for Julien. Given the increase in the G&A savings for 2012, what are you thinking for 2013? You left the guidance unchanged, might there be further savings fair, and then how does that play into your 8% to 10% total return target?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. The savings that we expect from the more focused strategy and the simplification of our portfolio are substantial. And we expect to achieve at least $65 million this year, at least $100 million by the end of next year. Before we wo
componenttext: That's a good question. The savings that we expect from the more focused strategy and the simplification of our portfolio are substantial. And we expect to achieve at least $65 million this year, at least $100 million by the end of next year. Before we would raise the number, we would really like to have more time and more concrete. Part of that will depend on the number of markets quite frankly that we exit in terms of going forward. Additional markets that we would exit. So in summary, we spent at least $65 million this year, at least $100 million, and this is a run rate going forward to the end of next year.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Andrew, this is Andrew Vesey. The process of that we're receiving the interest and the competitive bids, my understanding that these will be opened in I think mid September, if not late September. We will also be proposing our own hopefully cost-com
componenttext: Okay. Andrew, this is Andrew Vesey. The process of that we're receiving the interest and the competitive bids, my understanding that these will be opened in I think mid September, if not late September. We will also be proposing our own hopefully cost-competitive option for that. To the degree that we would be making capital investments, those most likely would be recovered at our next rate case. And then prior to that, we would begin AFUDC treatment if were to the building this project and I want to say following that it's a competitive process at this point in time. So there are many opportunities. One that we could build, somebody else can build, we could buy the capacity, buy the energy many ways to go through this. If we were to build this project, it's most likely would wind up going into rates at our next rate case.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: You touched on the Eletropaulo decision and the fact that as 16% ownership, it's a smaller part of the company's earnings. Was wondering if you could touch on it in the context of Brazil platform? And whether you consider selling Eletropaulo?
componenttext: You touched on the Eletropaulo decision and the fact that as 16% ownership, it's a smaller part of the company's earnings. Was wondering if you could touch on it in the context of Brazil platform? And whether you consider selling Eletropaulo?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I mean, we have -- in terms of large markets where we're present, Brazil is a market with a rapidly growing energy demand and where we have a very substantial footprint. We still have a lot of unlevered capacity, leverage capacity,
componenttext: That's a good question. I mean, we have -- in terms of large markets where we're present, Brazil is a market with a rapidly growing energy demand and where we have a very substantial footprint. We still have a lot of unlevered capacity, leverage capacity, I should say, which is a contracted 3,000 megawatts of Hydro. When we look at what Eletropaulo, we do own, 16%, we did develop the telecoms outside of Eletropaulo. And we also have the footprint in the South in the business of Zoll. Our footprint in Brazil is more than just Eletropaulo. We are one of the players there, and we do have the capacity to grow. And we do have now very good relations with BNDES and can finance new project. We will do projects, of course, that are good projects. So that's -- we have the capacity for growth, but we're making sure that we grow from good projects. Regarding Eletropaulo, we have in effect in the process of reducing our position there since 2006. We sold down half of our holdings, and we took out the telco. So the important thing for us is Eletropaulo is more -- we felt more regulatory challenges than other business there. And that given -- we have I think, given what we could do we've managed, as well as possible. So right now, with we're focusing on is making sure that we make it as a profitable business, as possible within the new guideline. And this is our second major cost efficiency program that we're doing that is creating value. We have done prior to that. So I guess, in a nutshell, we still see Brazil is an interesting market. We still have that critical footprint, and we still have the unused leverage at Kinect, which I think we are going to be focusing on. Eletropaulo has been challenging and we've done everything we can to restore profitability of that business.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the positive drivers we have is, first, the cost cuts that we've done this year. The second, the project that of come online fully. So we do have projects, for example, Angamos, so in Chile you, which for the first half of the year, were contract
componenttext: Sure. So the positive drivers we have is, first, the cost cuts that we've done this year. The second, the project that of come online fully. So we do have projects, for example, Angamos, so in Chile you, which for the first half of the year, were contracted at about 65% or now 9% contracted for the second half of the year. So we'll enjoy the benefit of a full year for that. So on '13, we'll have the full benefit of a lot of the construction projects which inaugurated at the end of last year. We also see cost cuts coming in and as well as we have complete [ph], win projects coming on as well. So there are a number of positive things coming on for 2013. But we also -- we've always pointed out that '13, given -- we're coming off a base of 20% growth in 2012. So given that our projects are lumpy, it's not going to be a similar year to 2012. And we have now the issue of what will the MRO filing look like for 2013 for DP&L.

componenttext: Waiting for potential settlement, you keep calling it procedural MRO? I mean, it's based on the other utilities feels like it's going to be an ESP. But if you could comment about who why it's taking so long? Is it someone linked to the other regulatory procedures pending? And also, you mentioned that power prices in Ohio are positively correlated with natural gas prices. But we have seen a pickup in natural gas prices over the last couple of weeks. And yet know how you power prices are actually flat to slightly down. And how that ties into your visibility about profitability of the business?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, let's take 1 at a time. In terms of the timing, there are 26 interveners in the process. And there's a wide range of interveners. So that's one thing that's taking some time. Regarding the second, in terms of power prices and Ohio, and in relationsh
componenttext: Okay, let's take 1 at a time. In terms of the timing, there are 26 interveners in the process. And there's a wide range of interveners. So that's one thing that's taking some time. Regarding the second, in terms of power prices and Ohio, and in relationship to natural gas, what we're saying is that basically, DP&L's fleet is coal for the most part, and it's scrapped coal for the most part. But nonetheless, it's competing with gas on the margin. So that is one thing that's affecting the profitability of those plants going forward. It's the same case, for example, to a much lesser extent in IPL in the sense that we do sell into the wholesale market and we do have coal plants, which are competing with coal. I do know if any would like to add some colors so some of the questions the whereas.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2012
componenttextpreview: The only other thing th I would -- to the first point about why it's taking so long, thank you probably all are aware that the procedural schedule was on hold to they would've been the date that interveners would have to file testimony and August 27 was t
componenttext: The only other thing th I would -- to the first point about why it's taking so long, thank you probably all are aware that the procedural schedule was on hold to they would've been the date that interveners would have to file testimony and August 27 was the last date for the evidentiary hearing, which would have signaled the end of the settlement process. By petition of the parties, the schedule has been suspended because the fact is everyone is working hard to bring this to settlement. So I would our probably see that still desired by all parties, all 26 parties, some of whom are our competitors sentiment be reached and we're still hopeful center said, hope opening remarks, end of the third quarter or early fourth quarter. And I think the suspension of the settlement, I mean, the schedule is signal of that there's no new schedule and the other time in the schedule we put into place basically say they cannot get to settlement. So still of the settlement past. I think on the other side, going into 2013, the foreign currency 2013 on average about $2.50 plus, that's the low for that business given the range of outcomes. We're hopeful as we get into 2014 with a pickup capacity prices and continually strengthening of the gas curves, we'll see this business start to take a much more positive trend as we've said in the past calls.

componenttext: We had outages at several of our large coal plants that have not been repaired. So we were out where we had budgeted to be in service.
