headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, and welcome to our third quarter earnings call. Our earnings release presentation and related financial information are available on our website at aes.com.Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during th
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, and welcome to our third quarter earnings call. Our earnings release presentation and related financial information are available on our website at aes.com.
Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during the call. There are many factors that may cause future results to differ materially from these statements. Please refer to our SEC filings for a discussion of these factors.
Joining me this morning are Andres Gluski, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Thom O'Flynn, our Chief Financial Officer; and other senior numbers of our management team.
With that, I will now turn the call over to Andres.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ahmed, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our third quarter earnings call. I hope that all of you in the North East have had your power restored at home and have fully recovered from Hurricane Sandy. We at AES have done as possi
componenttext:
Thanks, Ahmed, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our third quarter earnings call. I hope that all of you in the North East have had your power restored at home and have fully recovered from Hurricane Sandy. We at AES have done as possible to help the impacted areas, sending more than half of our available field resources from DP&L and IPL help out affected service providers.
Now turning to the third quarter results, I'm pleased to say that our financial performance this quarter improved over both the second quarter of this year, as well as the third quarter of 2011. This was expected and keeps us on track for our full year guidance. Adjusted EPS of $0.36 in the third quarter brings our year-to-date total to $0.91, which is $0.10 higher than what we earned in the first 9 months of 2011. The story is similar for our cash flow metrics. All in all, we are confident in our ability to deliver on our guidance commitments for 2012.
Additionally, we recently announced organizational changes that will create greater efficiencies by placing functional and operational activities in the right place and eliminating overhead redundancies. These changes are in line with our strategy and built on the cost savings that we had implemented over the past year. I will discuss the financial benefits of this reorganization in some detail later on in my remarks.
Today, I'd like to focus on 2 main topics: First, an update on recent development in our core markets including DPL in the U.S., Brazil and Chile; and second, progress on our strategic plan to unlock shareholder value, including deleveraging, returning cash to shareholders and improving profitability. Later, Tom will work you through the specific drivers of our results as well as our near-term outlook.
Turning to Slide 4. I'd like to provide you with an update on recent developments at DPL. As we announced last week, we determined that a goodwill impairment of between $1.7 billion and $2 billion of DPL was required. As we have discussed in prior earnings call, the fundamentals of the business have been adversely affected since the acquisition was announced in April 2011. This is primarily the result of sustained lower natural gas prices and more customers moving to competitive retail providers, including our own, have reduced margins. Consequently, forecasted profitability and cash flows are lower resulting in the goodwill impairment in the range we have provided. 
Obviously, we are disappointed with these developments at DPL. That said, we are committed to reaching the most positive regulatory and business outcome possible. To that end, we're working to achieve a reasonable result in the rate case, and we continue to expand our retail customer base inside and outside of DP&L's service territory and we will strengthen DP&L's balance sheet by using its internally generated cash to pay down debt.
Our electric security plan or ESP application is that design to balance DP&L's need to maintain its financial integrity the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio's desire for more rapid evolution to market-based rate. If approved, the proposed ESP will allow DP&L to collect a non-bypassable service stability right that will give the company an opportunity to earn a reasonable return on equity. The approval process is moving forward and the pre-hearings and technical conference have been scheduled for November 9. We are hopeful that the new ESP will be in place by no later than the first quarter of 2013. In the event that a decision or settlement is not reached by the end of 2012, we have also filed a motion with the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio requesting an extension of DP&L's current rate until a final decision is reached.
Next, regarding our strategy to grow our retail customer base, we continue to expand our retail load inside and outside of DP&L's service territory in Ohio. Within DP&L's territory, we have retained roughly 75% of switch load although as I said earlier, at significantly lower margins.
The markets outside of DP&L's service territory, both in Ohio and Illinois, our retail business is currently serving more than 150,000 customers. By year's end, we are projecting that DPL's retail business will be serving approximately 200,000 customers, which represent a net increase of approximately 175,000 in the company's total number of customers during 2012. 
Finally, we are working to strengthen DPL's balance sheet through a multi-year deleveraging and refinancing program. In 2012, we expect that DPL will distribute to AES $122 million, of which we've already received $87 million as of the end of September. Over the next couple of years, however, we expect to use essentially all cash generated from operations within the DPL group of companies for debt reduction.
Next, turning to Slide 5 and our businesses in Brazil. As many of you are aware, in order to stimulate the economy, the government of Brazil recently announced an energy cost reduction program or Provisional Measure 579, which targets a 20% reduction in electricity prices. About 1/3 of this planned reduction is expected to be driven by lowering indirect taxes on the sector. The remaining 2/3 of this reduction is being targeted through negotiations with various generators and TND companies, whose concession contracts are up for renewal between 2015 and 2017. These rules are still pending congressional approval and implementation is scheduled for February of 2013. 
I would like to emphasize that the proposed rules are not expected to have any significant impact in the near term on our businesses in Brazil. Let me explain why. Tietê, our main generation business in Brazil, has a long-term concession expiring in 2029 and thus will not be subject to this regulation. Furthermore, we are insulated in the short term as 100% of Tietê's output is contacted with Eletropaulo through December 2015. Beyond 2015, it's still too early to tell what the incremental impact of MP 579 will be on energy prices in Brazil.
As far as the impact on our 2 distribution businesses, Eletropaulo and Sul, we do not expect any meaningful impact on either. Both utilities earn our return on their regular asset base and energy purchases are treated as a cost -- On balance, the Brazilian government's initiative to stimulate economic growth should help increase demand for electricity, which will result in increased revenue for both Eletropaulo and Sul.
Now turning to Slide 6, I would like to give you a brief outlook on ASNL. I'm happy to report that all of our plants are fully available, including those that were offline in the second quarter for repair and maintenance. As discussed in our previous calls, our Angamos plant in the North of Chile is now 90% contracted and therefore it's exposure to low spot prices has been significantly reduced. In addition, we continue to see energy demand growth of between 4% and 6% in Chile. We have also seen positive results at some of our other important businesses, including Masinloc in the Philippines, -- in Bulgaria and south plant in the U.S.
Turning to Slide 7, I would like to provide you with an update on the strategic plan to unlock shareholder value that we laid out late last year. Just as a reminder, our 3 strategic objectives for enhancing shareholder value are: First, optimizing capital allocation; second, improving the profitability of existing portfolio; and third, narrowing our geographic and business focus by selling nonstrategic assets.
Now turning to capital allocation on Slide 8. As we have discussed in the past, our goal is to maximize risk adjusted returns on a per share basis by allocating our discretionary cash across various uses, including deleveraging, share buyback, offering a predictable and growing dividend and investing in platform expansions. Last month, the board approved the prepayment of $225 million of corporate debt, which we expect to complete later this year or early next. This will help us not only lower our interest expense but will also help us with our credit metrics by mitigating the impact of lost earnings in cash flows from assets that we have sold. Once completed, the prepayment will bring our total debt repayments to approximately $717 million since September of 2011, including both corporate level debt and expensive nonrecourse debt at our Brasiliana subsidiary. 
With respect to share repurchases, in the third quarter, we repurchased 4.3 million shares for approximately $49 million, representing an average price of $11.38. This brings our total investment in our shares since September of 2011 to $390 million representing nearly 34 million shares or approximately 4% of shares outstanding.
Last but not least, we have also declared our first cash dividend in almost 20 years, which is set to be paid on November 15. The dividend is an important component of our total return proposition.
Now please turn to Slide 9 and let's discuss our actions to improve our profitability. As you may recall, in late 2011, we announced an effort to reduce SG&A by $100 million by 2014. For 2012, we're ahead of our original goal of $50 million and we now expect to achieve at least $65 million in cost savings this year. As a result of the recently announced reorganization, we now expect to realize the full $100 million of savings in 2013. Ultimately, the reorganization will result in additional savings of $45 million to achieve a total reduction of $145 million in annual overhead expense relative to 2011. I would like to point out that the cost saving numbers I just mentioned only reflects savings in overhead at the AES level, and they do not include additional cost savings at our businesses, such as Brazil, where we are implementing our program to improve that company's performance by $224 million per year by 2015, of which $150 million will be achieved by the end of 2012. We see additional opportunities for savings in fuel sourcing and in operations and maintenance expenses. For example, we presently purchase $2 billion of coal a year and we're saving about $80 million as a result of implementing a comprehensive global sourcing framework, including the blending of coals and having the ability to redirect coal shipments. However, we believe we have not yet exploited all of the advantages from our global scale and possible synergies and are working hard to do so.
Moving to Slide 10. Let us review our progress in terms of narrowing our geographic and business focus through asset sales. Last quarter, we announced the sale of our China portfolio. I'm pleased to report that we have closed and received $86 million in the process for 2 of the 3 businesses. We expect the third transaction for $49 million to close within the next few weeks. To date, we have sold 9 assets for $933 million net equity proceeds at an average PE multiple of more than 20. We continue to seek additional opportunities to streamline our portfolio by exiting those markets where we do not have a competitive advantage or a strong platform with an opportunity for expansion. Once completed, we expect that this strategy will result in a lower overall risk profile and a more focused and efficient company.
In summary, we believe that we are consistently executing on the plans that we laid out in our first call last November.
Now Tom will review the drivers of our quarterly results, guidance and platform expansion projects in more detail.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andres, and good morning all. Before I get into our results, I would first like to say that I'm very pleased to be here. In the past couple of months, I've learned a lot about the company, the people, the culture and the business. Like any company
componenttext:
Thanks, Andres, and good morning all. Before I get into our results, I would first like to say that I'm very pleased to be here. In the past couple of months, I've learned a lot about the company, the people, the culture and the business. Like any company, there are a number of exciting aspects and also some challenges. However, I've been impressed by the commitment of our people, as well as the potential for improving our portfolio, delivering attractive returns to our shareholders and the other things that Andres has laid out. 
This morning, beginning on Slide 11, I'll cover the following topics: first, our third quarter results and key drivers of gross margin, adjusted earnings per share, adjusted pretax contribution and free cash flow and parent liquidity; second, our near-term capital allocation plans; and finally, an update on our guidance and total return expectations.
As Andres has mentioned, we reported $0.36 of adjusted EPS for the third quarter. This brings our 9-month earnings to $0.91 or about 3/4 at the low end of our full year 2012 guidance.
Now to Slide 12, our proportional gross margin increased by $168 million over the third quarter of 2011. The majority of this increase was driven by new businesses, such as Changuinola in Panama, Angamos in Chile and DPL in the U.S. In addition, we saw a favorable year-over-year trends at several of our larger generation businesses, such as Masinloc in the Philippines and Moritza in Bulgaria. These trends were partially offset by lower tariff rates and higher fixed costs at Eletropaulo in Brazil.
Now turning to adjusted EPS on Slide 13. Third quarter results increased by $0.08 or 29% to $0.36. This increase was primarily driven by $0.09 of contributions from new businesses I just covered, $0.01 from -- share count and $0.02 from our cost-cutting initiatives, which have lowered SG&A expense by $26 million in third quarter and $57 million year-to-date. These gains were partially offset by unfavorable foreign exchange impacts of about $0.03.
Now to Slide 14. I'd like to review our new earnings metrics we're introducing this quarter. We hear frequently from investors with a large number of businesses can be difficult to determine what is the biggest impact on the bottom line. In an effort to provide additional transparency, we are introducing adjusted pretax contribution, metric that we use internally to measure financial performance. This measure is calculated by taking the pretax earnings from each business, putting those accounted for as equity and earnings and adjusting for our ownership or segments. In addition, we make the same pro forma adjustments that we do for adjusted EPS. 
On Slide 14, we draft the relative contribution to each of our segments have made to year-to-date adjusted PTC of $1.5 billion. As you can see, for example, Latin America generation at 37% is the single largest contributor driven primarily by our generation flip at Chile, the Dominican Republic and Brazil. Our generation businesses in Europe and North America are also significant contributors. 
We measure also highlight of some of our business consolidated results are significantly different than the bottom line impact. This is most notable in Eletropaulo, which we control and consolidate but have an economic interest of only about 16%. As shown on the slide, our utility businesses in Latin America contribute only 8% of adjusted PTC. We hope this additional disclosure will help simplify the AES story and allow you to focus on the biggest value drivers.
Now to Slide 15. On a proportional basis, our free cash flow is increased $41 million compared to the third quarter of last year. This increase was driven primarily from contributions from new businesses partially offset by a decline in Eletropaulo.
Now on to Slide 16, in parent liquidity. During the quarter, we benefited from $426 million of inflows from asset sales and cash flow from our subsidiaries. Also during quarter, we returned 71 million to shareholders by share repurchases. After $157 million of corporate interest, overhead and investments, we ended the third quarter with more than $1.2 billion of parent liquidity, up from $1 billion at the end of last quarter.
Now to Slide 17. I'd like to discuss our plans for capital allocation for the balance of the year. This year, we expect to generate $1.6 billion of discretionary cash. Year-to-date, we've already allocated 67% to returning cash to shareholders in deleveraging, including the $225 million debt paydown expected later this year or early next. We've allocated another 17% or $262 million to growth investments. The remaining 16% or $258 million of year-end cash will be combined with parent free cash flows in 2013 to be allocated in line with our capital allocation framework.
Now let me take a minute to review a couple of the segments for 2013. On the source side, we expect parent free cash flow to be lower than the 2012 expectations of our $550 million. It'll be due to 2 major factors, the first in DPL and secondly from AES and air and IPL, that those businesses retain some cash to reinvest. In terms of the use of discretionary cash, we expect growth investments to be lower than the 2012 levels of $262 million. These 2013 investments, which could total up to $200 million, are largely impact from expansions that I'll discuss in a moment. 
Regarding the dividend and growth, we expect to evaluate the reasonable list of dividend increases on an annual basis in the beginning of the fourth quarter, consistent with the timing of our annual planning process. We appreciate the value of moving our dividend yield to be more in line with the S&P 500 and we'll factor that into our future deliberations.
Finally, the main cash will be invested in both debt reductions and share repurchases with more weighting towards debt reductions in 2013.
Now to Slide 18. We are reaffirming our 2012 guidance elements that discussed on our last quarter's call. Consistent with our comments from last quarter, we expect to come in at the low end of the range of $1.22 to $1.30 adjusted EPS. Operational free cash flow and subsidiary distributions are also expected come in at the low end of our guidance range.
Now to Slide 19 and looking beyond 2012. We expect modest adjusted EPS growth in 2013 compared to our 2012 expectations. This modest growth is largely driven by improved operating performance at AES Gener in Chile, recovery at Eletropaulo in Brazil and the full year benefit in capital allocation and our cost savings initiatives. These benefits are partially offset by lower earnings in DPL and weaker foreign exchange. 
Please keep in mind this is based on foreign exchange and commodities as of September 30, our expectations of near-term regulatory and the current macro outlook each of our key markets. We expect these items change, our guidance could be impacted. This guidance assumes extension of the controlled foreign corporation or CFC provision recently enacted under TIPRA. As in prior years, we expect Congress will retroactively extend this tax legislation later this year. If the CFC tool is not extended before year end, we estimate an impact of $0.02 to $0.03 this year. Recall that this will be a non-cash impact as we have an outstanding net operating loss carryforward of about $2.1 billion. 
Overall, we continue to project tax rate on adjusted earnings in the low 30% range.
Andres has discussed we continue to look for opportunities to streamline our business focus. Although most of our focus to date to have been EPS neutral to accretive, this may be more difficult as we monetize on assets. Prior to releasing a defined 2013 guidance range during our year-end call, we'll have an update view of relevant macro environments and the impact of potential portfolio de-risking activities.
Now to Slide 20. Earlier this year, we introduced a 3-year average annual total return target of 8% to 10% comprise of EPS growth and dividend yield. Since our last earnings call, we made considerable progress in our annual planning process and although not fully complete, it is evidence to us that our earnings growth rate in 2015 will likely be lower than previous estimates. This decline was driven by lower earnings from DPL in 2014 and '15 due to the issues that Andres has covered. We have been anticipating some improvement in DPL which is no longer the case. In addition, the compounding effect that produced cash flow also has an impact.
Secondly, lower-than-expected earnings in Brazil, driven largely by lower demand, unfavorable foreign exchange rates and a more negative outcome than expected on the tariff reset in Eletropaulo. These are partially offset by improved performance in our businesses in Chile, IPL in the U.S. and the additional cost savings we recently announced. In light of these factors, we're now expecting an average total return through 2015 of 6% to 8%. We appreciate that this is a difficult provision but believe it is a more appropriate reflection of our current outlook.
Before turning the call back to Andres, I'd like to cover the progress we're making on our almost 1800 megawatts of projects under construction, as well as our platform expansions underdevelopment. Moving to Slide 21, our construction program remains on schedule. In addition, we've already secured the necessary financing and funded 100% of our equity commitments for these projects. In terms of progress on these specific projects, the work at our 270-megawatt coal-fired Campeche project in Chile is progressing well. I was in Chile a couple of weeks ago and had a good first-hand look at the progress. Synchronization of the unit is scheduled for November and commercial operation is expected in early 2013. The project at 216-megawatt gas power plant in Cameroon, we've energized a 60-mile transmission line and plan testing will begin in December. Finally, our 1240-megawatt coal-fired plant in Vietnam is progressing on time and on budget, and operations are expected to begin in 2015. We're especially pleased that this project has surpassed 5 million man-hours without a lost time incident and is achieving world-class EP standards.
Now to Slide 22. In terms of future value creation beyond these construction projects, we continue to move forward on developing powerplants in markets where we have a significant presence in a compelling competitive advantage. Our focus is to use most efficient source of capital, including bringing in strategic partners, using low-cost project financing, multilateral funding and operating cash flows generated at the existing businesses. For example, at Cochran, 530-megawatt coal-fired expansion in our Angamos platform at AES and Gener, we now place and place contract, long-term the majority output and are close to bringing in a strategic partner. We're focused on finalizing project financing and construction is expected to begin in 2013. 
With regard to Alto Maipo, the 530-megawatt under project also at Gener, we successfully executed the principal construction contracts, moved forward works, continue to work remaining project milestones and expect to begin construction also in 2013. Similarly, here in the U.S., we plan to upgrade 100% of baseload coal-fired fleet at IPL with investments in environmental controls to comply with MAPS. This investment will earn regulated returns and will also fulfill a majority of necessary environmental upgrades required for -- at all of our 7000 megawatts of coal-fired generating here in the U.S. We expect this investment to begin second half 2013 carrying on through 2016 with potential equity investment of up to $300 million.
In closing, I look forward to seeing many of you next week in the EI. I'll now turn it back over to Andres.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Tom. Let me summarize what I've seen are the key points of this call. We're pleased with our third quarter results which are in line with expectations. We're on track to delivering 20% adjusted EPS growth this year in line with our guidan
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Tom. Let me summarize what I've seen are the key points of this call. We're pleased with our third quarter results which are in line with expectations. We're on track to delivering 20% adjusted EPS growth this year in line with our guidance. Despite the challenges we have faced recently, the earning power of the company ring strong and we expect to deliver a 6% to 8% average annual return from 2012 through 2015, including dividend yield and EPS growth. Although we won't be satisfied with this rate of return, we believe it's prudent to lower expectations at this time primarily given lower forecast from DPL and Brazil. But we will, nonetheless, continue to strive for higher total returns for our shareholders. We have taken actions to significantly reduce our overhead and streamline our organization. We will also aggressively pursue additional operating cost savings. We will continue to de-risk the company to deleveraging and narrowing our geographic focus through asset sales and we're committed to pulling all levers to improve risk-adjusted returns from our platform businesses. Finally, along with Tom, Andy Vesey and I will also be at the EEI next week and we look forward to seeing many of you.
Operator, we'll now open the line for questions.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from John Cohen with ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from John Cohen with ISI.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question is on the parent free cash flow. Tom, you said that next year, you expected to be somewhat lower than the 550 midpoint of this year and then you said growth CapEx was expected to be more in the $200 million range and the remainde
componenttext: I guess my first question is on the parent free cash flow. Tom, you said that next year, you expected to be somewhat lower than the 550 midpoint of this year and then you said growth CapEx was expected to be more in the $200 million range and the remainder of will be skewed more toward debt repayment. First of all, is there a good way of thinking about what the long-term parent free cash flow contribution from the subsidiaries is? Is that something less than 500? I mean, how do we think about what that's going to be longer-term? And secondly of your $6 billion of recourse debt, do have a target of mind of where you going to get that down to? At what point would you be comfortable with the current cash flow profile, what level of debt you think is right at the whole count?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, John, good questions. In terms of next year, I touched on it briefly but the 550 from the Slide 17 I think it was, will be lower next year really partially because of reduced cash coming from DPL. But also, we're making reinvestments in a couple of
componenttext: Okay, John, good questions. In terms of next year, I touched on it briefly but the 550 from the Slide 17 I think it was, will be lower next year really partially because of reduced cash coming from DPL. But also, we're making reinvestments in a couple of businesses. As I mentioned, IPL and secondly, Gener. The number of the-- so we expect that to be lower. We'll give you better idea of what our expectations will be on our year-end call, we'll be giving guidance. I think so the 500-ish range is a more indicative indication of a more normalized number. So this year would be closer to what we think would be a more normalized number. Next year, it'll be lower, below the let's say a 500 normalized number because of reinvestments we're making. In terms of the CapEx, I said up to 200, I do mean up to 200. One of the biggest things, it could be as little as half that amount. One of the issues is Gener has been a great performer for us, a great grower. They are building the 2 projects: coal in and the Hydro. Coal come first, Cochran I've mentioned. That issue was that they will need some equity at the Gener level to do that. And the 200 would contemplates of equity being put in by AES obviously, another alternative is them issuing shares in the market to do that. So well known company, good market cap, trades well, trades better than us. So as one of the things will think about is that the right funding is to the extent that they access the majority of the equity in the markets are so maybe there's splitting the baby concept and that 200 could be as low as 100 to 100 and a quarter. There's something we'll have to give thought to. In terms of go back to the third party question, the 6 -- I thing it's $6.2 billion of parent debt, including some trust preferreds but we will look for coverage ratios. I think we've said that we want to maintain our rating and work it up over time but the coverage ratio we look at in terms of debt to cash flow, can work use the range of 4.5 to 5.5, that continues to be a target that we've got. Near term, we're a little skewed towards the higher end of that range so 2015, some of our cash flow available may be weighted more towards a share repurchase but once again, we see that really as that 2013 only focus. We've got the ability to do both but we really focus kind of bottom-line. We focus on the leverage -- the coverage ratios. As you know, that's a more appropriate condition of credit quality.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: John, this is Andres. What I'd like to say with Gener, we'll continue what we've done successful. So truly capital and tax efficient to really use some of the resources at Gener rather than setting them up and sending them back down. And as Tom mentioned
componenttext: John, this is Andres. What I'd like to say with Gener, we'll continue what we've done successful. So truly capital and tax efficient to really use some of the resources at Gener rather than setting them up and sending them back down. And as Tom mentioned in his speech, we're also again partners, partners that bring not only financing but they bring access to bilaterals, actions,  cetera. So really, we're optimizing. Gener, it will continue to do that as and I think the one change from the past is looking more partners and we did is partly due to budget financing it's getting tougher everywhere. So we'll continue to do it Gener what we've done and looking for the most tax efficient way to do so and create the most value.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012

componenttext: Our next question comes from Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: In terms of debt reduction, could you just provide perhaps a multiyear view, I mean, within that 4 to 5.5 range, just kind of how quickly do you want to get there, if you will.
componenttext: In terms of debt reduction, could you just provide perhaps a multiyear view, I mean, within that 4 to 5.5 range, just kind of how quickly do you want to get there, if you will.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's 4.5 to 5.5, Chile, don't upgrade me to quickly here. But I think we want to stay within that 4.5 to 5.5 range. We want to bring it down to the lower end of that range over, let's say, a 3-year period as the talk about overall numbers here. We th
componenttext: Yes, it's 4.5 to 5.5, Chile, don't upgrade me to quickly here. But I think we want to stay within that 4.5 to 5.5 range. We want to bring it down to the lower end of that range over, let's say, a 3-year period as the talk about overall numbers here. We think about things to '15 that would be where we want to get to and that's a rough kind of '15 range. So as you know, that's a fuzzy both cash flow of the business, as well as absolute debt.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And could you provide just a little bit -- I mean, in the past, you've describe discrete EPS contributions going into '13 like for the something or something or to that extent, could you provide a bit of sense year-on-year growth drivers more granu
componenttext: Great. And could you provide just a little bit -- I mean, in the past, you've describe discrete EPS contributions going into '13 like for the something or something or to that extent, could you provide a bit of sense year-on-year growth drivers more granularity?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, the 2 main -- what were basically happening in 2013 is one, we have Campeche coming online. We have a 4-year more contract in Angamos In Chile, one of the things that has affected our results was this year, we were somewhat short and sick in
componenttext: Sure. I mean, the 2 main -- what were basically happening in 2013 is one, we have Campeche coming online. We have a 4-year more contract in Angamos In Chile, one of the things that has affected our results was this year, we were somewhat short and sick in the South and prices were very high because of poor hydrology and we were actually somewhat less contracted than our final objectives in the north and their prices were very low because that basically people had to take-or-pay gas contract. So those things get corrected. We also have in terms of some of our wind projects in the U.S. as the tax equity say matures that we will have more earnings from those assets in the U.S. and we'll also have the new plants that have been brought on for the full year. So I think that those are some of the drivers that we have. We can give you perhaps some more specific breakdown of the small plants but it's a different situation than we were this year with a big driver, we had a lot of megawatts coming online at the beginning of the year.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible].
componenttext: [indiscernible].

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just a follow-up on asset sales. You kind of executed in the most part in the bulk of the describe call earlier this year. What's the next round? Or is there another around here in that you're contemplating? And where at least from a geogra
componenttext: And then maybe just a follow-up on asset sales. You kind of executed in the most part in the bulk of the describe call earlier this year. What's the next round? Or is there another around here in that you're contemplating? And where at least from a geographic perspective, where should we think about that, what kind of assets perhaps, more renewables?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. I think that sort of go back to what we laid out, we said we had a universe of about $2 billion of equity in assets that we can sell and so we've executed about half of that and that we would be concentrating on those that weren't
componenttext: That's a great question. I think that sort of go back to what we laid out, we said we had a universe of about $2 billion of equity in assets that we can sell and so we've executed about half of that and that we would be concentrating on those that weren't sort of platforms for growth that had unused leverage capacity or ability to raise money or really places we didn't feel they had sustainable competitive advantage. So I think we've done that pretty much to date. Now going forward, what we do the same framework is in place, we don't really like to really give specific names because, of course, we're operating these businesses and if we say they are for sale, it makes it more difficult to continue operating them at the optimal level. But again, there would be those where we have like 1 plant, one-off where we don't see a platform of growing. Regarding renewables, we have changed the way we think about most renewables certainly win. We're not thinking about a stand-alone wind business but really thinking of placing wind into sort of geographic units that we have. So wind becomes just another way of providing energy. And what we've seen is we really exploit the sort of platform concept there more successful. If you think of something like battery storage, we are leaders explaining let's say this technology and where we really been successful is where we apply it to our existing businesses. The one exception of this is solar. In solar, we have a 50-50 JV with Riverstone and, of course, both of us will be seeking to monetize this asset over time. But other than that, I really can't give you more specifics but I would say, you should expect over time, a continued asset sales. This will also help us reduce cost, help us reduce our focus and what we'll do is as soon as really have something firm, announce it and make it public but we don't want to get ahead of ourselves here.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ali Agha with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ali Agha with SunTrust.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: And you alluded to this a little bit in your closing remarks but I wanted to pick on that 6% to 8% total return that you're projecting for the next 3 years, I'm just curious where do you benchmark yourself against? And I mean, how do you justify that as a
componenttext: And you alluded to this a little bit in your closing remarks but I wanted to pick on that 6% to 8% total return that you're projecting for the next 3 years, I'm just curious where do you benchmark yourself against? And I mean, how do you justify that as an acceptable return for investors looking forward when you look at alternative investments particularly in the power utility space? And I guess a related question to that, does that cause you to step back and look at your portfolio and say, are you in the right mix of business given that kind of return that this portfolio generating for you?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think first of all, let's step back a second. This year, we're growing earnings 20%. So I think that would probably certainly rank as among the top of our peers in this space. So I think what we're doing is coming off a growth of 20%. Now what we have d
componenttext: I think first of all, let's step back a second. This year, we're growing earnings 20%. So I think that would probably certainly rank as among the top of our peers in this space. So I think what we're doing is coming off a growth of 20%. Now what we have done is really look at adapting to what we see is the new forecast for DP&L, some of the FX and some of the tariff in Brazil and just saying, we want to be prudent, we want to overachieve whatever we give out there is guidance. So that's really what's causing this step down of 2%. But I think that if you think of our portfolio, again, if you take a longer period, we do have very competitive growth rates. I think that we provide the advantages of a diversified portfolio. Obviously, we're concentrated in fewer markets. You have less of this but I do you think and we have said from day one that we do think that we're into many markets and so we do want to focus that we can have all the advantages of the portfolio diversification. We don't have to be in 30 countries as where we started. So yes, do expect us to reduce, do expect us to become more efficient as I think we're doing. I mean, we're -- we've reduced overhead. By next year, we'll be close to 25% and the longer term, it's more like 1/3. And that's just overhead in terms of managing these businesses. So regarding your question, I do think that we will provide compelling returns. We are in the right markets, markets where there's growth. Chile's growing 5% to 6%, Columbia is growing 5% to 6%, panama's growing 8%, even Brazil longer term is expected to be growing at 4% after 1.6% this year. So I think it's hard for you to find another portfolio that has these growth rates and I think we have a clear strategy for executing on them. So yes, we're not where we want to be at the end but we certainly take big steps in right direction.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012

componenttext: Also just to clarify your expectations over the next 3 years, the portfolio expansion opportunities that you guys highlighted in your slides, are those already baked into that growth as well?

componenttext: Yes. Those are baked in. Now of course, if there's other things that we can do in terms of some of the renewals that are shorter construction time periods, those are not in there.

componenttext: The only thing that I would add is -- the growth not yet the construction which is IPL in the 2 projects in Gener. IPL, we do get earnings between now and '15, we do have a track really get the return on construction in progress. The 2 projects at Gener are not going to be earnings generators until '16 and '17, respectively.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then separately, if my math is right, I think you pretty much used up your current buyback authorization with this last 49 million purchase. Is that right? And when should we expect an increase in net authorization or what you're thinking, you
componenttext: Got it. And then separately, if my math is right, I think you pretty much used up your current buyback authorization with this last 49 million purchase. Is that right? And when should we expect an increase in net authorization or what you're thinking, you alluded to that, Tom, you did as well on your commentary. But when should we see some expansion of that authorization assuming that you to still want to buyback more stock?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, your math is right. We did execute on our authorization. What I would say is just as I said in the past, we can always get very quickly and authorization to have more buybacks. But I would say, if you go back to what I initially laid out a yea
componenttext: Okay. Well, your math is right. We did execute on our authorization. What I would say is just as I said in the past, we can always get very quickly and authorization to have more buybacks. But I would say, if you go back to what I initially laid out a year ago, what we said we were going to go buy back shares, we were going to strengthen our dusty by buying back debt, and we're going to execute on given some of the growth projects so pay the first dividend. So I think we're exactly executing on that and so we have done share purchases 4% from the starting point of total outstanding shares. And as Tom mentioned, we will now be focusing on deleveraging over the next short period. But I will make clear that for us to get an authorization to buyback more stock, we can do that on very short notice.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. One last question, one clarification, you alluded to TIPRA expansion assumption. Was that just talk about 2012 and the $0.02 to $0.03 impact? Or is that baked in for the full next 3-year outlook?
componenttext: Okay. One last question, one clarification, you alluded to TIPRA expansion assumption. Was that just talk about 2012 and the $0.02 to $0.03 impact? Or is that baked in for the full next 3-year outlook?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our guidance for '12 and our total return guidance or expectations through '15 do assume an extension of TIPRA, the $0.02 to $0.03 I talked about would just be the impact in '12 in the event it wasn't extended. It would be in a high single-digit number in
componenttext: Our guidance for '12 and our total return guidance or expectations through '15 do assume an extension of TIPRA, the $0.02 to $0.03 I talked about would just be the impact in '12 in the event it wasn't extended. It would be in a high single-digit number in the event it was not extended permanently. So that would be let's say '13, '14 number. That's before other tax strategies that we can pursue. To be honest that high single-digit number is called $0.07, $0.08. Yes, the 6 months number would be higher but we continue to about ways to mitigate so a total TIPRA termination of I can -- if that's technically correct would, as we sit here today, on an ongoing basis with the high single digits. We've been very successful in mitigating that down and we continue to do that. I think in general view, there has been good support in our view the election results last night just on a TIPRA-only basis is that the current administration, the Senate, the finance committee, they've all general been supportive of this. And if that same folks are generally coming back to their desks, that's helpful to TIPRA expansion.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would say 2 things. Remember when we talked first about the non-TIPRA expansion at the beginning of the year, we're talking about impacts of about $0.10 before mitigation. We had a down to $0.02 or $0.03. And the second thing, remember this is
componenttext: Yes. And I would say 2 things. Remember when we talked first about the non-TIPRA expansion at the beginning of the year, we're talking about impacts of about $0.10 before mitigation. We had a down to $0.02 or $0.03. And the second thing, remember this is non-cash that we have $2 billion of NOLs. So yes, we do expect it to be extended but if it weren't, as Tom mentioned, we would be taking other measures to decrease that impact than we think we can be successful to bring it down sort of the range we have this year or next year as well.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012

componenttext: Okay, the 7 to 8 just lastly, that was the annualized number, Tom, you were thinking about?

componenttext: Yes, that would be annualized number with no further mitigation. As Andre said, that would not be -- our expectation would be that we have some further mitigation that we have in the past.

componenttext: The ROE is embedded from -- it's actually the lag is from the last rate case which is in the 90s, so it's a good lack. And it's above what other utilities in the state are getting, just leave it there. I would say separately, IPL, separate tracker, they may consider going in for a rate case over the next 18 months, just as they've done well in the regulatory structure but maybe...

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. Sorry, Tom, I was just hoping to follow-up on your comment about going in for a case over the next 18 months. What was kind of the driver there in telco?
componenttext: A couple of questions. Sorry, Tom, I was just hoping to follow-up on your comment about going in for a case over the next 18 months. What was kind of the driver there in telco?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say that's -- the major driver of the financials at telco is their capital expansion and the tracker keeps them in comfortable position. They may have some comments, I'm probably getting ahead of the game in terms of talking about that in any kin
componenttext: Yes, I'd say that's -- the major driver of the financials at telco is their capital expansion and the tracker keeps them in comfortable position. They may have some comments, I'm probably getting ahead of the game in terms of talking about that in any kind of detail.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Gregg, this is Andy. I mean, the fundamental issue is that we managed in Indiana very well. We have a very constructive regulatory environment with the environmental trackers. We've managed our cost very well. We have among the highest level of reliabilit
componenttext: Gregg, this is Andy. I mean, the fundamental issue is that we managed in Indiana very well. We have a very constructive regulatory environment with the environmental trackers. We've managed our cost very well. We have among the highest level of reliability in the state. We have one of the lowest cost of service in Indiana. I think that when we talk about the current investment that we have which is to meet the federal regulations on submissions, of that, that's not driving us anywhere near rates. We do have the tracker and we believe the majority of those costs will be recovered as Tom explained. That's pretty straightforward. We've already submitted our certificate of public. I mean, it's necessity we're expecting that backwards shortly. I think I mentioned on the last cost -- call, what will make us think about whether we need to go into rates or not is how we deal with potential retirements of older coal units. We are looking at and still evaluating whether we may have to retire up to coal orders, more coal units which represent about 15% of our generation. If we do that, we probably will have to bring on new capacity in the self builders through the RFP process that we engaged in earlier. As we come to that decision, we would only be able to recover costs associated with that expansion in a rate case, and that's really what's out there. And as we get further along that process, we'll update you probably in the next call where we are but that's really what Ton was alluding to the potential that if we have to do the retirements and we do added capacity at that point, we will need to consider going through rates so we can recover on that investment.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on, sorry for the question, but on 2014 earnings, you kind of catch 2013 as below the modest growth, below the trendline that you're laying out. Given that there aren't a lot of megawatts coming online in '14, how do you see '14? Would that
componenttext: Okay. And then on, sorry for the question, but on 2014 earnings, you kind of catch 2013 as below the modest growth, below the trendline that you're laying out. Given that there aren't a lot of megawatts coming online in '14, how do you see '14? Would that be below trend? And then catch up in '15?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit to soon for us to provide guidance but we do have, again as I mentioned earlier, some of our businesses such as U.S. wind, for example, by the end of '15, will be adding about $80 million of pretax contribution, adjusted PTC beca
componenttext: I think it's a little bit to soon for us to provide guidance but we do have, again as I mentioned earlier, some of our businesses such as U.S. wind, for example, by the end of '15, will be adding about $80 million of pretax contribution, adjusted PTC because due to the tax equity. So right now, it's too soon to give that. But obviously, if you have 1 year that's below, you're going to have other years that are above to get you to the average.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And sorry, last question. Just coming back to the $2 billion asset sale target. That was kind of laid out a year ago. How do you think about that at this point? Is that up for revision? Or what are your thoughts there?
componenttext: Right. And sorry, last question. Just coming back to the $2 billion asset sale target. That was kind of laid out a year ago. How do you think about that at this point? Is that up for revision? Or what are your thoughts there?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would like to just make one clarification. I never said there was a $2 billion target. I always said that there was a universe of $2 billion, and that we expect it to sell a high percentage of that but not 100% necessarily. So we never had a $2 bil
componenttext: Yes. I would like to just make one clarification. I never said there was a $2 billion target. I always said that there was a universe of $2 billion, and that we expect it to sell a high percentage of that but not 100% necessarily. So we never had a $2 billion target. Now in terms of the sales, I mean we did sell those. I think that we're in a good position to sell for a very good multiples quickly and I think our market timing was very good. Now looking forward, we're going to sell judiciously in the sense that we really want to maximize that the value of this and I can give you just an illustration assume, we could have sold factories to all of our China assets and we did have offers to sell it right away but we took our time and sold those to separate buyers and we received the 40% premium versus the sort of altogether and that's how we're going to continue with these asset sales. So I think when we have several things under discussions and when we really do have something that we can bank on, then we will announce it. So we're working hard on this. But I don't want to get ahead of ourselves and say that we have something until we actually have it signed. So do I feel that if we reached to, say, $1.7 billion or $1.5 billion, if we got the right price then that's probably the right amount. Again what's important is that we got as much value out of it and the second thing, which is also very important is do we end up with the optimal company. Do we have the assets that we can administer efficiently that help add to the hole in terms of our synergies in our scale? So what's really important is that just the amount of money that's coming in but do we end up with the right company at the end of the process?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question, Brian Chin with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question, Brian Chin with Citigroup.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the dividend, you gave a little bit of color that each year, you'd come looking at the dividend level and thinking about the appropriateness and the reasonableness of that and then you mentioned the reference to the S&P 500 dividend yie
componenttext: Just a question on the dividend, you gave a little bit of color that each year, you'd come looking at the dividend level and thinking about the appropriateness and the reasonableness of that and then you mentioned the reference to the S&P 500 dividend yield which is right now around 2%. Am I right in thinking that the next time you'd be thinking about that is sometime in the second half of next year? And what are some of the considerations that you're thinking of in terms of moving that dividend to an S&P 500 number or not?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's correct. But what we said is -- what Tom said is we evaluate this is part of our normal process. This is our first dividend and we will reevaluate it towards the second half of next year. We had always indicated moving towards more sort of an avera
componenttext: That's correct. But what we said is -- what Tom said is we evaluate this is part of our normal process. This is our first dividend and we will reevaluate it towards the second half of next year. We had always indicated moving towards more sort of an average for the S&P. And I also said that we have a lot of new businesses coming online and we want to see how all of them performed forward reviewing this. So that will be basically it. We're basically looking at our cash flow, how other businesses are performing. But I think our intention of giving a portion of partner free cash flow back to our investors in the form of the dividend remains strong and those are that is our objective longer term.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's correct. So some of the comments when you say in terms of how our growth rate compare, we're coming off a growth rate of 20%. So this is following 20%, we're saying 6 to 8. And I also want to make clear that we're including, of course, also the div
componenttext: That's correct. So some of the comments when you say in terms of how our growth rate compare, we're coming off a growth rate of 20%. So this is following 20%, we're saying 6 to 8. And I also want to make clear that we're including, of course, also the dividend as well. That's our total return to shareholders.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012

componenttext: Right. And then one last unrelated question. You had indicated a part of the reason why you were changing the growth outlook was DPL and what's going on with the new ESPN also different switching level assumptions. Can you clarify a little bit more what level of retail switching are you assuming at DPL in your now new outlook? And can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing out there with the resident a lot of competitive dynamics coming from synergy and other folks out there. So what are you guys seeing out there right now?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll ask Andy Vessey. Can you answer that one?
componenttext: I'll ask Andy Vessey. Can you answer that one?

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: Brian, it's Andy. Let me talk about our outlook on switching and I want to sort of put this in the context of the ESP filing, which is essentially our view of Ohio. ESP filing, what we've done is we've locked in you're going forward in the switching of 62
componenttext: Brian, it's Andy. Let me talk about our outlook on switching and I want to sort of put this in the context of the ESP filing, which is essentially our view of Ohio. ESP filing, what we've done is we've locked in you're going forward in the switching of 62%. That is really what the switching was from the end of August. We also proposed somewhere to the AEP as a switching tracker so that fundamentally, we would be able to not have to forecast switching where forward but that you would be held sort of neutral to switching return forward to the outcomes of the rate case. That said, most of the battle right now is around residential customers. We have seen an increase in residential customer switching about 2.5% a month. We see an probably around 75% switched. We're seeing most of the category of customers other than residential reaching saturation levels, so that's really what we're seeing. It's mostly been increases organic switching because I think a lot of the aggregate have slowed downed pending the outcome of all the cases and actually the elections that we've just had. So we anticipate that we're going to see continued very intense competition in the residential class. We see that potentially saturated long term at about 80% -- 86% switched. So were competitions intense and, as Andre said, we are replacing more customers and we lost in more load than we've lost. But clearly, it's an extremely competitive environment.

headline: The AES Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2012
componenttextpreview: So given that you've embedded a rough 60% switching number plus tracker in your assumptions than if you don't get that switching tracker and you believe saturation is closer to 80%, then that might be one negative headwind down the road. If you don't get
componenttext: So given that you've embedded a rough 60% switching number plus tracker in your assumptions than if you don't get that switching tracker and you believe saturation is closer to 80%, then that might be one negative headwind down the road. If you don't get that tracker in ESP?

componenttext: Sure. This is Andy, and I'll talk a little bit about the first part of your question and let Tom talk about the issues around generation, restructuring. In light to that piece, the issues that have been around the discussion at the beginning when we filed the MRO and have the settlement discussion, the 3 main issues, it's time to market of our loads before competitive. It's been on bypassable will charge and emerging sharing those initial settlement discussions have been this question of legal separation of the generation assets even though we believe that the functional separation than we have today actually is fighting competition. What we've done in the filings we addressed all these issues. We have made -- we are not asking for any approval to separate generation in the current ESP filing. And as you know, we filed ESP in October 5. What we have been estimated commitment in the current filing that welcome back by the end of the year with another filing specifically talking about the transition of generation looking towards legal separation by the end of 2017. With that said, I think that answers part of the structural question, I want to ask, Tom wants to answer the second part of the question.
